question: Right calcaneus of an adult female raptor. Mild stress fractures. What's this tell me? It tells me that this bone connects to the navicula which we already found articulating to the cuboid. So, what can we stay for sure? Stress fractures in the heel ...
answer: She jumps.

question: Right as rain, Ellie. Now, why did she jump?
answer: A defensive posture against a vicious, blood-thirsty T-Rex?

question: Perhaps. Or maybe to select the smaller, more tender leaves in the higher branches with which to suckle her young?
answer: I bet is was a mating ritual.

question: The science of paleontology can't answer these questions. Novelists and artists who dream a vision of the Jurassic period can attempt these questions with their imaginations. What we scientists can say is considering the mass and kinetic articulation of these bones, this animal had a vertical leap of about twelve feet. Not as entertaining as fiction, but absolutely fact without prejudice.
answer: Excuse me, Dr. Grant. But ... fact is, we're late. There's the car.

question: Jim, you keep making up the plaster batches. Whatever ratio you're using, it's perfect. Nora, no digging after five - when the temperature drops, those bones are just too brittle. Bill, I don't want any tourists walking over my raptor - I don't care if the Governor of Montana is with them, just you guys.
answer: You know, if ev ery scientist stuck to his method like you, there would be no body of theory - no quasars, no big bang -

question: Jesus, a limousine. We're re-entering Hammond's world, that's for sure. Remind me why we're doing this, Ellie.
answer: We're leaving the raptor dig -

question: - at a critical time -
answer: - because Gennaro is paying us sixty thousand dollars to observe some resort of Hammond's in Costa Rica. And that's -

question: We can't trust Hammond anymore. He's under too much pressure. There's the EPA, he's behind schedule, and the in- vestors are getting nervous. There have been too many rumors, too many accidents. We can't screw around with this.
answer: I've asked Hammond to arrange independent site inspections every week for the next three weeks. Insists nothing's wrong on the island.

question: You know him. Do you believe him?
answer: No, I don't. I spent a lot of time with him five years ago when we raised the capital. And it was a wild ride. He's unpredictable, a dreamer.

question: Potentially dangerous. We should never have gotten involved. What's our position?
answer: The firm owns five percent.

question: General or limited?
answer: General.

question: We should have never done that.
answer: It seemed wise at the time. We all wanted the park to happen. It was in lieu of fees.

question: In any case, I agree an inspection is overdue. Who are your site experts? Will they tell the truth?
answer: I think so. That guy Grant's a hotshot in his field, always goes his own way -

question: - Good. You're making all the arrangements?
answer: Hammond asked to place the calls himself. I think he wants to pretend the park is not in trouble. That it's just a social invitation, showing off the island.

question: Welcome, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to an ancient and mysterious world, a world long before humankind inhabited it with all out remarkable dreams and questions. Enter a world that existed one hundred million years ago. When our changing earth was the abode of magnificent creations.
answer: - the furious haste to commercialize genetic engineering.

question: Biotechnology promises the greatest revolution in human history. It will outdistance atomic power and computers in its effects on our everyday lives. We'll see square trees for easy lumbering and white trout for super visibility to fisherman. Why it will transform every aspect of human life
answer: Here we go.

question: It's been a long time, Alan. I know the preceding was not your sort of enter- tainment. Popular science -
answer: No, I don't mind popular science. I dislike the commercialization of science. It breeds a sloppiness, a disregard for method.

question: Well, I don't disregard method. But think of mutation - which is nothing more than sloppy communication on the cellular level. Think how triumphant mutations have been in natural selection.
answer: Mr. Hammond, the essential truth of a scientific law ha s nothing to do with public reaction. Water freezes at thirty-two degrees, whether you pay for it or not.

question: Although Dr. Grant suspects otherwise, this is not an ill-conceived, half-baked, poorly funded plan that I've headed. This is a plan to which I committed all of my personal resources, literally billions of dollars. And Donald Gennaro here has kindly helped me raise that sum again from wealthy Japanese. They love theme parks. I have recruited pre- eminent scientific minds from hallowed universities and we've taken the time to do things right. Jurassic Park is the most advanced amusement park in the world. We work with genetics - life's essential building blocks - to create new worlds. I set out to make biological attractions. Living attractions. Attractions so astonishing that they'd capture the imagination of the entire world.
answer: What exactly do you mean ... biological attractions?

question: As you well know, long ago, creatures ten times larger than whales roamed our adolescent Earth. And then mass, mysterious extinction created a time barrier unscalable until ... now.
answer: Yes?

question: You're both right. Amber is our gold. The alpha or our alchemic alphabet. The precious course of our genetic material. You already know amber is the fossilized resin of prehistoric tree sap, of course. Imagine - millions of years ago, tree sap flowing over insects, as it does now as I speak, in thousands of forests and backyard trees everywhere. Imagine that ancient sap trapping a little struggling insect and consuming it in a syrupy death. Millions and millions of years pass and we come along and discover this prehistoric insect. If we're lucky, he's perfectly preserved in a fossil form inside the hardened sap which is now amber. And as we examine more and more amber, we find many perished insects, including among them, biting insects -
answer: Like mosquitos -

question: Like mosquitos, precisely, Dr. Grant.
answer: Mosquitos that sucked the blood of dinosaurs. That's your source of DNA

question: The extraction room speaks for itself.
answer: It does?

question: Right you are, Dr. Grant! More like hundreds of thousands of mosquitos are necessary to provide even a partial strand of DNA. And without a complete strand, we don't have a dinosaur. Ah, I knew you two would hit it off! Dr. Grant, this is Dr. Wu, my chief geneticist.
answer: Finally, you are here! I've been working without the encouragement of my peers for too long. Welcome, welcome! Mr. Hammond never lets me publish and he's interested only in results, not in science.

question: Don't forget to thank me when you pick up your Nobel prize. You are standing in the middle of the most powerful genetics factory created since the expulsion from Eden.
answer: These are Hamachi-Hood automated gene sequencers, those are Cray XMP's, supercomputers that take DNA information and organize it. In this room, we take fragmented or incomplete DNA strands and compare them to other incomplete strands.

question: It's like finding the missing pieces of a jigsaw puzzle.
answer: The computers make sever al trillion calculations to provide us with a complete DNA strand - the genetic code of an extinct animal.

question: Reptile eggs contain large amounts of yolk but no water at all. The embryos must extract water from the surrounding environment.
answer: That's why you create the mist.

question: Children, please do not touch! The eggs are permeable to skin oils.
answer: What kind of eggs are these? Are these shells plastic?

question: These raptors are too damn dangerous. One of them tunneled out this morning. He ripped a boy's arm off before I could get a bullet in him.
answer: A bullet? Muldoon - no! Now what? I have five left?

question: John, they're mean as scorpions and smart as chimps. Their little fingers make them natural cage-breakers. We should terminate the raptor program. They're just too smart. Too damn smart.
answer: Oh balls. I will not terminate the raptors just because they're behaving normally. They're hunters. Why can't we contain them properly?

question: John, remember back in '88, when we started to build the containment devices?
answer: It's just a zoo, Muldoon. A zoo. Figure out a way to contain them. And we'll sit down and have a nice long discussion about raptors - after my guests leave, okay?

question: Okay! Get a 'dozer, start digging round the pit. We're gonna bury some fence. And wear your rifle when you're working!
answer: Wh ere are they? Punch 'em up.

question: You know, Dr. Grant, Hammond likes to come here in the evening and just sit.
answer: Where is the T- Rex?

question: Good question.
answer: Maybe she's down hunting apatosaurs.

question: Would if she could, believe me. Some- times she stands by the lagoon and stares at those animals, and wiggles those little forearms of hers in frustration. But the T-Rex territory is completely enclosed with trenches and fences. Believe me, she can't go anywhere.
answer: Then where is she?

question: Damn those people. They are so negative.
answer: It's natural. They can't fully appreciate that we've engineered the animals and the park for total safety.

question: They comb this island like a bunch of accountants. They don't experience the wonder, the awe of it all.
answer: You can't make people experience wonder.

question: It's like the Garden of Eden out there. This is the most beautiful time of day.
answer: Better rout the tour back. They can start again sun-up tomorrow morning.

question: What's going on, Arnold? I want those lights on. I don't want my grandchildren scared.
answer: Jesus, the computer's gone down.

question: Well, I want the computer up. This is the wrong weekend for glitches.
answer: That's not the worst of it.

question: Nedry? With an incubator? Regis??
answer: That's what they saw.

question: We gotta tell Hammond and Arnold right away. How far is it to the mainland?
answer: Uh, it's a hundred miles to Puntaremas. About a sixteen hour voyage in this weather.

question: I'm hungry. When can we get going?
answer: When the electricity comes back on, honey. These cars run on electric cables buried in the road. Must be turning on the electricity.

question: Feels like a vibration.
answer: Jesus Christ.

question: Bad language.
answer: Jesus Christ. The fence isn't electrified.

question: Oh shit! Oh shit, oh shit, oh shit, oh shit!
answer: Timmy. Are you ok?

question: Thank God you're here. Where's Lex?
answer: Below. She's fine. Let's get you down. Try the door you're leaning against. Nice and slow. Crawl this way. Slowly. We're going to have to make a jump for it, Timmy. Okay? One, two, three, jump.

question: Thanks, Dr. Grant.
answer: You owe me one. Where'd Lex go?

question: There's Lex.
answer: Come on out now, Lex.

question: I'm afraid of the "animals".
answer: The "animals" are gone.

question: Where did it go?
answer: I don't kno w but it's not here now.

question: Oh, My God! Where's the other one?
answer: Ellie! Wait up. T-Rex tracks.

question: Then they must be out there. They must be out there. I know it.
answer: Perhaps.

question: No! They're out there.
answer: I've seen a lot of animal attacks in the bush. It's not as gory and horrifying to see as you'd think. No pools of blood or exposed bones. There is usually little or no evidence left behind. And if victims are small, a predator can kill by just shaking the little thing to death, eating it, and leave not so much as a button. Thank God. We have to carry him. First I have to ... He's losing a lot of blood. Help me.

question: Looks like you've been through this before.
answer: I told you I've seen big game attacks in Africa.

question: Why?
answer: Because Nedry messed with the code. That's why I'm checking it.

question: But that could take weeks. What would be faster? Try keychecks.
answer: That's true. Keychecks will give me a record of every button Nedry pushed. Jesus, that's all he did all afternoon? He was just dicking around, maybe waiting to get his nerve up.

question: What's that?
answer: Some sort of object. Let's see if we can trace it.

question: What's it mean?
answer: It wasn't a bug. It was a trap door that fat bastard left for himself. When he hit WHTE-RBT. OBJ, it initiates a set of commands that turned the whole goddamn park off. Hammond was right about him.

question: We found Gennaro. He'd badly injured. Harding's tending to him in your quarters. He'll be all right if we can
answer: I'm sure you'll find them.

question: I certainly hope so.
answer: I'm sure we will. After all, I keep telling everyone, this park is made for children.

question: Just so you understand that they're missing, sir.
answer: Missing? Of course I know they're missing. You just said that. Look, Bob, let's not get carried away. We've had a little breakdown from the storm or whatever, and as a result we've had a regrettable, unfortunate accident. And that's all that happened. We're dealing with it. Arnold will get the computers cleaned up, and the radio and phone lines open. You'll find those kids and my good friend, Dr. Grant. I'm sure they'll want some of this ice cream. It's very good.

question: But I'm tired-tired.
answer: Okay, Lex. Oof! You're heavy. I think we're still in his paddock. What?

question: Don't you see? Don't you see?
answer: What?

question: The fence.
answer: No.

question: A herbivore grazing area. Excellent.
answer: We gonna walk all night?

question: Twelve hours before that ship reaches the mainland.
answer: We need sleep.

question: Up there.
answer: Climb? Again? I can't climb again?

question: What is taking Arnold so long? This room is too cold. My eggs will be damaged.
answer: No sign of those berries. Really interesting. There are indications of a similar virus in every tissue sample. But it's not in the ground. Could I look at some of the discarded embryos?

question: I'm sure you'll find your virus ... or a similar one. All animals carry many viruses in a dormant condition. It's almost impossible to say with certainty which are the same strains.
answer: And yet from what Harding tells me, many of you animals have similar symptoms - besides the microvesicles, a lack of hunger, loss of reproductive urges, sores in the mouth and gums.

question: What is it?
answer: That's it.

question: That's what? The fences and the power?
answer: Right. And it does something else. It erases the code lines that refer to it. It destroys all evidence it was ever there.

question: Nedry could steal the eggs, get back and reset the whole show. No one would ever miss him.
answer: Watch this. Hot damn!

question: Are the fences back on?
answer: You bet they are. It will take a few seconds to get up to full power, because we've got fift y miles of fence out there, and the generator has to feed the capacitors along the way. But in a half a minute we'll be back in business.

question: Motion sensors?
answer: Got them too. It will be a few minutes while the computer counts. Then I'll tell you where Grant and the kids are and you can go and get them. But every- thing's working. Half past ten and we've got the whole thing back up and running.

question: Just hiss. What is taking so damn long? Where are they?
answer: There's a lot of extraneous movement out there. Branches blowing, birds, back- ground movement. It may take, ah, okay, count's finished. Hmmmm. I don't see them. Maybe they're out of range of a sensor.

question: Whoa! Giddyup! Whoa!! Take is easy! I can't swim!
answer: Go home now. Home to Freda!

question: Oh, let him stay. He likes me to ride him. He could carry me instead of you, Dr. Grant. Please, let him stay,
answer: Go! Go away. Go! Get out of here!

question: Will I ever play with him again?
answer: We gotta get to that motion detector. It's still a ways.

question: Who gave you permission -
answer: I'm here to investigate this park. And there's plenty you haven't told me.

question: That's absurd.
answer: These bones aren't fully formed.

question: You're qualified to interpret x-rays of living dinosaurs? I doubt it. It took me many months to learn. You're making a lot of assumptions here.
answer: Right. What the hell is going on, Wu?

question: Growth hormones.
answer: She didn't have a right to explore my lab.

question: Let's not argue, Wu, we have a serious problem. These animals don't last. There is a regularity, a predictability about when they die. It's always ... very young. We don't know why. Given time, I'm sure Wu will figure it out. It's just ...
answer: Just some adjustment in the code is required.

question: Nedry jammed all the communication lines. He inserted some command, a lockout into the program code. I can't find it, because I gave that restore command and it erased part of the program listings.
answer: So? Just reset - shut the system down and you'll clear the memory. Everything will be in the normal wakeup mode.

question: Shut the system down?
answer: And reset.

question: I've never done that before. And I'm reluctant to do it. Maybe it's tr ue, all systems will come on, but maybe they won't.
answer: Look, there is a sick man here who needs medical attention or he'll die. Four people are out there, missing in your park. We need search teams. We have to have a phone or radio. Well?

question: Well, it's just that the safety systems don't function with the computer shut down and -
answer: - turn the goddamn safety systems off! Can't you get it through your head that we have no choice?

question: Okay. You asked for it. And you got it.
answer: How long do we have to wait?

question: Memory should be cleared by now. Damn.
answer: What's wrong?

question: Oh hell! I have to turn the safety switches back on before I restart the power. Thank God!
answer: Arnold! They're still not working.

question: Nope. Too scared.
answer: You ready?

question: Can we go on the raft? Then we don't have to walk so close to the animals!
answer: What raft?

question: Where I found Freda's baby.
answer: It's still mid-morning. I bet we have at least ten miles to go. If we take the raft along the river, we can make much faster progress.

question: It's still mid-morning. I bet we have at least ten miles to go. If we take the raft along the river, we can make much faster progress.
answer: Let's do it.

question: Lex, I don't see any raft.
answer: Keep going.

question: Bullseye!
answer: Told you!

question: No raft. Where did you see it, Lex?
answer: Actually, I never really saw one. Just assumed.

question: I'm afraid there's no raft. Looks pretty calm.
answer: I'll row, Dr. Grant.

question: No.
answer: Hey, we're still moving.

question: There's a current.
answer: You can't sleep.

question: I'm not sl eeping... yet.
answer: I'll do it!

question: This doesn't mean the fences have been off since six-thirty, does it?
answer: Backup power doesn't generate enough amperage to power the electrified fences, so they were automatically kept off. That's also why we had no phones or radio.

question: All of the fences?
answer: Yes.

question: Including the velociraptor mesh?
answer: Yes, yes, yes.

question: Any candy behind the counter?
answer: Hungry?

question: Starved.
answer: Nothing.

question: Let's go to the kitchen.
answer: Dr. Grant said -

question: - let's go. We'll come right back.
answer: Nope. We're waiting here t ill Dr. Grant gets back. He'll help us get some - Start winding now!

question: We'll freeze to death in there.
answer: He's going to eat us!

question: PUSH!
answer: What is it, Timmy?

question: Queen Anne, do you read me? Queen Anne?
answer: This is the Queen Anne B? I copy. What's up?

question: Report your position!
answer: Ah, we're just about to dock here in Puntaremas. Who wants to know? Please identify yourself.

question: Try this for identification, Captain Farrell. You are in possession of stolen biological materials. If you don't turn that boat around and return to Isla Nublar immediately with your contraband cargo, you will be found in violation of Section 509 of the Uniform Maritime Act, you will be subject to revocation of license, penalties in excess of fifty thousand dollars, and five years in jail. Do you copy? Do you copy, Captain Farrell?
answer: I copy. All ahead stern.

question: Well it gives us ten more hours. Let's see if we can raise the Costa Rican Coast Guard on that thing. And then there were none.
answer: Dr. Grant, don't abandon this beautiful place. I need a man just like you to help me get my park back on its feet again. And it will be on its feet again.

question: We have to leave now.
answer: Oh you don't know. There are wonderful plans in the works, sites already purchased for Euro-Jurassic and Jurassic Japan. Don't you see I've exalted human potential here? You must see it. You must feel it. I called back a life form. Listen, Dr. Grant, don't go. Be a part of this. I'm inviting you to do just that - let the others go, if they want.

question: You interrupted natural law. There are regulations, rules that nature follows that make her knowable.
answer: You mean there are rules that nature follows that create barriers to our knowledge.

question: Barriers? Like the seasons? The earth spinning, orbiting the sun? The entire solar system in interlocking motion. Our own beings in biological step with it all. Mr. Hammond, you've disrupted the pattern and look what it's done!
answer: I know what it's done. I've made triceratops and gallimimus and a T-Rex. I've got a batch of iguanadons being born on Tuesday. What do you say to that?

question: Don't count on it. Now get in. You created mutant forms that you further mutated to create amus ement attractions. You made biological puppets with heartbeats and an early death sentence.
answer: I created genetic miracles!

question: You created a park to generate a profit- making merchandising operation.
answer: The merchandise is just a by-product. Souvenirs for people to reflect on the wonder. You fainted when you saw the brachiosaur. Alan, look, let's not argue. The problem is that my employees were not up to par with my dream. They failed me. The park, I promise you, is safe. It really is.

question: You park is doomed. Now come with me.
answer: It is not! It's blooming! In the throes of labor! You are one more more negative voice in a universe of negativity. You'll amount to nothing. You'll be a bone-brusher all your life. I pity you.
